b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:37): hmm. what the commenter on the above forum sees as evidence supporting profile='' is exactly what 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e sees as evidence that profile='' has failed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:37): the commenter goes "See WordPress uses it" and 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e goes "See, it is almost always used incorrectly, like WP."
77db19c1dd94414f199e58aa6ca1827f (09:41): analysis of existing web content is primarily applicable to studies of existing language features
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:42): so it's not exactly right to say "For something to become part of the HTML WG's recommendation it has to be in use."
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:42): on the other hand, there is a presumption that features from existing specs that are almost never used or almost always used wrong are probably flawed

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:43): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: analysis of existing content also shows demand for certain use cases that could be addessed by the core spec instead of scripts and plugins
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:43): it's a different kind of evidence
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:44): obviously we do have things in the spec that aren't in use
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:44): personally I don't see what profile gets you that you couldn't put in a <meta> or <link> tag, for something like GRDDL
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:45): and for microformats profile is clearly unhelpful and indeed useless
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:45): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: if GRDDL does foo, anything that's not foo is an inconvenience to the GRDDL users
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:45): anything that's not foo but replaces foo that is
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:45): there are so few GRDDL users that inconveniencing them is irrelevant

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:46): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: the interesting part is that the GRDDL reason to have profile is to deal with microformats but we've seen that otherwise profile is unhelpful and useless for microformats
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:47): what exactly does wordpress do with the profile attribute anyway?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:47): I couldn't find it on the few wordpress blogs I looked at

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:47): to me this suggests that if GRDDL wants to be successfull at working with microformats *on the Web scale*, GRDDL should figure out how to do it without profile
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:48): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: profile="http://gmpg.org/xfn/11" as seen on blog.whatwg.org
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:49): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: so basically, whenever a WP blog uses a non XFN microformat, the theory says that the other formats don't mean anything
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:50): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: so it would be useless to let the profile value constrain what microformats you look for
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:51): GRDDL requires the document to have more markup in the document than just the profile attribute, right?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:52): I don't know what exactly GRDDL requires
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:52): it has to be, first of all, the GRDDL profile, not the relevant microformat profile(s)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:52): whoa. that would be *so* not Web scale
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:52): and then a <link rel="transformation" ...> to the GRDDL xsl stylesheet
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:52): http://www.w3.org/2004/01/rdxh/spec#grddl-xhtml
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:52): if I'm reading this right
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:53): so the publisher has to participate in a GRDDL-specific way instead of merely using a microformat
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:54): the profile attribute says that rel="transformation" should be interpreted as a GRDDL transformation
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:54): it doesn't say anything about what microformats you use and afaict GRDDL doesn't care about that
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:54): but I could be misunderstanding this
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:56): although one of them links to GRDDL transforms for FOAF, CC and Geo, without profile markup for any of those
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:56): I quick glance over the GRDDL spec suggests to me that we should just add transformation to the list of known rel values

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:56): so yeah, the idea of GRDDL is that your document's data can only be extracted by GRDDL-aware processors if you have marked it up in several GRDDL-specific ways, the most relevant ones not being the profile attribute
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:58): I wonder if there's a quotable about XSLT similar to the jwz regexp quotable...
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (09:59): XSLT requires use of XPath as well, so you have at least three problems
